msDesc.head: Letter from Maria Edgeworth to Thomas Spring-Rice, Baron, Monteagle of Brandon 1790-1866, Black Castle, Ireland,

editorialDecl.p: Edgeworth’s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, including non-standard spelling, line breaks, and hyphenation of words. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

div.p:
It is impossible that any
black marks I can make
upon paper can convey to
you the idea of the concern
I feel for these changes —

It is not for you or for Lord Lansdowne
Lansdowne that I feel but for Ireland — the loss of place
and power may for aught
I know may be again of happi-
ness happiness to you both — But the
loss to Ireland of such friends
in power is I fear irremedia
'ble irremediable —

I have much that I wish
to say to you, which I cannot
& ought not to put on paper
— for instance - circumstances
I have privately learned from
catholics respecting late distur
bances disturbances in this Town of Navan
— and elsewhere —

The hand of despotism
may press down & keepdown
a nation if that hand be strong
enough — But the hand must
be in that case never be removed
& must never relax —
To the conqueror of Waterloo
The reconquest of Ireland would
appear & be easy perhaps; & there
fore his miln genius may brave
& despise the danger of putting
things to this issue — But — after
wards — he must be prepared
to exterminate - he can
no otherwise extinguish publicopinion

Cromwell— who was better
made for the purpose than
any other man stopped short
of the mark & after wading
through slaughter to his
church left 50,000 to tell
the tale —

But I have no business with
these things --
NB. I do not think from what I have
heard that the priests would dare
to let themselves be paid by Govt
unless Cat - eman. were same time granted
— Great debating may be upon the means
& tenets of said words — we shall hear from
the Pope I suppose soon — & from you? — When?

You were so very kind to
my brother William— another
brother of mine — Sneyd E —
now begs me to recal him
to your memory — These are
his words

"Now thatSpring Rice is not in
"office can you Dr. Maria give me
"a pretext for calling on him —
"I should like much to renew my
"acquaintance with one whom
"I foresaw would be a distinguished
"man when I met him at Edward
"Smedley's chambers at Trinity"

It will gratify me and
my brother much if you can
give him half an hour of
your conversation — I enclose
a note for him — Send it by
2d post. It contains a little note
of introduction for him to you
which is all I can do for him

He is a more literary man
than William & having seen
a great deal of the world
abroad for many years has
more that will make half an
hour's conversation agreeable
to you — Oblige me — and I shall
be obliged — which is more than
many people who ask favors
can promise or at least more
than they are often found to per
form
div.closer:
I am Yours very sincerely
Maria Edgeworth Feb 8th 1828
